qas.question: From when are the earliest dated Sanskrit inscriptions?
In what script are the earliest Sanskrit inscriptions?
In what language was Brahmi first used?
What language is the descendant of Sanskrit?
How were early sacred texts offered?
When were the latest inscriptions in Sanskrit known to exist?
When was the earliest Vedic script known to exist?
What written language is known to occur centuries later than Sanskrit?
Where are there Prakrit inscriptions dating from the third century?
What king's pillar is the most recent Brahmi inscription found on?

context: The earliest known inscriptions in Sanskrit date to the <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>first century<b6_0/> BCE<b5_0/><a0_0/>.[citation needed] They are in the <a1_0>Brahmi<a1_0/> script, which was originally used for <a2_0><a3_0>Prakrit<a3_0/><a2_0/>, not Sanskrit. It has been described as a paradox that the first evidence of written Sanskrit occurs centuries later than that of the <b7_0>Prakrit<b7_0/> languages which are its linguistic descendants. In <b8_0>northern India<b8_0/>, there are Brāhmī inscriptions dating from the third century BCE onwards, the oldest appearing on the famous Prakrit pillar inscriptions of <b9_0>king Ashoka<b9_0/>. The earliest South Indian inscriptions in Tamil Brahmi, written in early Tamil, belong to the same period. When Sanskrit was written down, it was first used for texts of an administrative, literary or scientific nature. The sacred texts were preserved <a4_0>orally<a4_0/>, and were set down in writing "reluctantly" (according to one commentator), and at a comparatively late date.
